# Corporate Social Responsibility

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority is committed to fulfilling its corporate social responsibility, with the goal of becoming a responsible and sustainable organization. The HKMA demonstrates this commitment in various areas, including promoting sustainable development and environmentally conscious markets, caring for the wider community, protecting the environment, and creating a friendly workplace.

To address the COVID-19 pandemic, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) has launched a series of measures to support individuals and businesses in need, thereby helping the Hong Kong economy navigate these challenging times.

# Market environment

# Green and Sustainable Finance

Climate change poses a significant risk to both human well-being and the sustainability of the global economy. As a critical part of the economic infrastructure, the financial system is inevitably vulnerable to its effects. Consequently, banks – integral to this system – must proactively manage climate-related risks. Recognizing this challenge, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) is actively pursuing solutions and implementing measures announced in May 2019 to foster green finance in Hong Kong. These initiatives include a three-phase plan to advance green and sustainable banking.

# First Stage

Establish a common framework with the industry to assess banks' current "green benchmarks," as well as collaborate with international organizations to provide technical support to banks in Hong Kong;

# Second Stage

Consult with industry and other stakeholders regarding regulatory expectations and requirements for green and sustainable banking; and

# Third Stage

Concentrate on implementing, reviewing, and evaluating the bank's progress in this area.

At the international level, the Monetary Authority participates in multiple international organizations, including the Green Finance Network of Central Banks and Supervisors, the High-Level Working Group on Climate-related Financial Risks under the Basel Committee on Banking Supervision, the Sustainable Finance Group under the Bank Supervision Working Group of the East Asia and Pacific Central Bank Meeting, and the International Sustainable Finance Platform. Through participation in these international organizations, the Monetary Authority has the opportunity to contribute to the efforts of central banks and regulatory authorities in addressing climate change, and can draw on the experiences and perspectives of other regions when developing local frameworks.

The Financial Supervisory Commission also participates in multiple working groups under the central bank and regulatory network for green finance, including the microprudential supervision working group, the macro financial working group, and the working group for promoting green finance. In addition, the Commission has joined two newly established working groups: the research working group and the working group for addressing data gaps. The research working group is responsible for related research work, while the working group for addressing data gaps aims to develop a detailed list of data items needed by regulatory authorities and financial institutions to assess climate-related risks and opportunities, but which are currently not available. Details of the Commission’s work this year in promoting the development of green and sustainable banking can be found in the “Banking System Stability” chapter.

In November, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) partnered with the International Finance Corporation (IFC) to launch the Green Commercial Banking Alliance, assisting banks in emerging markets in developing strategies to address climate change. As a founding member and the first regional executive director of the alliance, the HKMA i) drives the development of green commercial banking in global financial markets; ii) provides a platform for commercial banks to exchange knowledge, access tools and business intelligence, and formulate their own green finance roadmaps, transforming into credible green banks; iii) facilitates communication and explores cutting-edge issues to advance the global green agenda; and iv) supports collaboration among alliance members to seize the estimated $2.3 trillion in green and climate-related investment opportunities in emerging markets identified by the IFC over the next decade.

Locally, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) collaborates with other financial regulators to coordinate measures within the financial sector to address climate and environmental risks. In addition to assisting the government in implementing its green bond plan, the HKMA jointly established the Green and Sustainable Finance Inter-Agency Steering Group with the Securities and Futures Commission (SFC) to oversee cross-sector regulatory and market development. Details of the HKMA’s work this year in developing Hong Kong as a leading global hub for green and sustainable finance can be found in the chapter “Hong Kong’s Status as an International Financial Centre.”

# Green and Sustainable Finance Cross-Institutional Supervision Group

The Steering Group aims to coordinate the financial sector’s response to climate and environmental risks, accelerate the development of green and sustainable finance in Hong Kong, and support the government’s climate strategy. Jointly launched by the Hong Kong Monetary Authority and the Securities and Futures Commission in May, the Steering Group also includes representatives from the Environment Bureau, the Financial Services and Treasury Bureau, Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing Limited, the Insurance Authority, and the Mandatory Provident Fund Schemes Authority.

Since its establishment, the oversight group has established two technical task forces dedicated to researching and addressing cross-departmental regulatory matters, as well as coordinating cross-organizational market development initiatives.

The Oversight Group released the Green and Sustainable Finance Strategy in December, proposing to strengthen Hong Kong's financial ecosystem from six aspects, aiming to build a greener and more sustainable future in the long term. The Oversight Group also announced five short-term action plans to address some of the most pressing issues during the development process.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) held the inaugural meeting of its supervisory committee, with Mr. Yu Wai-man, the HKMA's Chief Executive (third from the right), serving as co-chairman of the committee.

The Steering Group released Hong Kong’s Green and Sustainable Finance Strategy and five key action plans.

# Responsible Investment

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) supports responsible investment, which involves integrating environmental, social, and governance (ESG) factors into investment activities. As a major asset owner, the HKMA is increasingly focused on responsible investment, and this will influence how its fund managers conduct their investment activities.

# The Hong Kong Monetary Authority's Beliefs

The Financial Supervisory Commission believes that emphasizing responsible investing and considering the sustainable long-term performance of various investments will more effectively achieve the investment objectives of the foreign exchange fund and reduce ESG-related risks associated with investment activities.

# Principles of the Monetary Authority

In line with the guiding principles adopted by the Hong Kong Monetary Authority, ESG investments are generally prioritized when their risk-adjusted long-term returns are comparable to those of other investment options. As a responsible long-term investor, the HKMA incorporates the following responsible investment principles into its investment management process as appropriate.

# Assimilation

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority believes that ESG factors will have a significant impact on the long-term value of investment projects, and therefore integrates ESG factors into the investment analysis process to identify risks and uncover opportunities. The HKMA incorporates ESG factors into the investment management processes of both public and private markets.

# Actively Exercising Asset Ownership

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority appropriately exercises its shareholder rights in listed companies to protect the long-term value of its investments. The HKMA believes that responsible corporate behavior, including consideration of ESG factors, contributes to long-term shareholder value. The HKMA expects external investment managers to actively exercise ownership by voting and communicating with investee companies, thereby assisting the HKMA in fulfilling its ownership responsibilities for its investment projects.

#Collaboration

The Financial Supervisory Agency is committed to collaborating with like-minded investors and regulatory bodies to promote sound long-term investment management practices, and participates in public events to deliver speeches, sharing improved ESG methodologies and encouraging the investment community to adopt responsible investment principles.

For details on the Financial Supervisory Commission’s work on responsible investment this year, please refer to the “Reserve Management” chapter.

# The Financial Services and Markets Authority, acting as a proactive and responsible investor, monitors the ESG practices of externally hired investment managers.

# Monetary Authority's Expectations

The Financial Supervisory Agency places great importance on incorporating ESG factors into investment decisions and proactively exercising asset ownership rights. To this end, the Agency considers ESG factors when selecting, appointing, and supervising externally hired investment managers. Believing that exercising shareholder rights regarding its holdings of listed company stocks is a fundamental principle for maintaining the long-term value of investments, the Agency requires appointed investment managers to take proactive asset ownership rights seriously.

# Oversight by the Monetary Authority

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) requires external investment managers to have their ESG performance assessed for listed stock portfolios under their management. Through a communication program, the HKMA systematically reviews these managers’ ESG practices across various areas, including their ESG assessment frameworks, engagement with investee companies, and proxy voting activities. In 2020, the HKMA selected several external investment managers to participate in this program, evaluating not only their ESG performance but also whether they were properly exercising asset ownership on behalf of the HKMA.

# Communication Outcomes

The HKMA identifies outsourced investment managers with problematic operational practices through the program and takes follow-up actions. The following are two examples.

# Case 1

The Financial Supervisory Commission has noted that investment manager A’s ESG framework has room for improvement, particularly in establishing a more systematic approach to evaluating investee companies. The Commission has followed up with A on this matter, and subsequently A conducted a comprehensive review of its corporate policies to implement a more robust ESG framework. A has also specifically appointed external consultants to provide input on ESG procedures, reflecting a determination to accelerate the implementation of reforms, and has established a new ESG Committee composed of senior management, demonstrating a commitment to ESG and the support of senior management for these measures.

# Case 2

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority, after reviewing the voting methods of stock investment manager B, found deficiencies in B’s voting policies across several areas and requested a review by its ESG head. In particular, B consistently approved management’s proposals, deviating from its own proxy voting guidelines. B subsequently committed to strengthening its voting policies to meet expectations, including increasing the involvement of ESG team members and potentially voting against management when facing significant governance issues.

In the realm of private market investments, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) achieves responsible investing through its dedicated fund managers, who actively collaborate with relevant portfolio companies on ESG matters. The HKMA has observed that these designated partners consistently uphold their commitment to ESG principles, as they believe this approach helps create long-term value for portfolio companies and ensures the sustainability of returns. The two examples outlined below illustrate how climate change risks can be managed through (i) design modifications and the application of innovative operational technologies, as well as (ii) integrating carbon-reduction factors into the construction and operation of green and sustainable warehouses. Both examples have made significant positive environmental impacts, reducing carbon emissions and avoiding harmful substances, while simultaneously enhancing operational efficiency through cost reduction and energy conservation.

(i) The Monetary Authority has invested in a pest control company that adopts an environmentally friendly solution. Although traditional insecticides and chemical products can effectively eliminate pests, failure to promptly remove or properly dispose of dead pests can pose a threat to public health. Moreover, leakage and disposal of chemical substances can also cause environmental issues. The company's solution, which does not involve biocides, reduces the use of harmful chemicals by setting up traps. It also utilizes internet-connected dynamic sensors to remotely monitor whether pests have been captured. Through this new technology, the company can make efficient route planning for collecting captured pests, reducing travel distance and thus lowering carbon emissions. The company's approach results in a low net carbon emission level of 0.36 kilograms of carbon dioxide equivalent per dollar of net sales, close to the average level of low-carbon industries such as legal services and software publishing, which is truly encouraging.

(ii) The Hong Kong Monetary Authority invests in green and sustainable warehouses. Although the construction industry is a major source of carbon emissions, the relevant warehouse developers adopt net-zero carbon emission processes throughout the overall construction and operation of the warehouses, establish standards and metrics for measuring net-zero carbon emission benchmarks, and take into account the sustainability of materials and components used in the construction plans. As a result, the warehouses built have high carbon reduction efficiency and possess sustainable features, including solar heating systems, electric vehicle charging facilities, natural lighting, and rainwater collection.

According to an independent consultant's assessment, the carbon footprint of the warehouse construction, calculated on a net basis, is 25.8% lower than that of a typical logistics building. To further offset the carbon emissions generated during construction, 32,799 trees were planted during the construction process (on a net basis). Once completed, the warehouse’s daily operations generate 26.9% less carbon emissions than those of a typical warehouse.

# 意見

茲證明我已審計列載於第187至289頁外匯基金及其附屬公司（「集團」）的財務報表，該等財務報表包括外匯基金及集團於2020年12月31日的資產負債表與截至該日止年度的收支帳目、全面收益表、權益變動表和現金流量表，以及財務報表的附註，包括主要會計政策概要。

我認為，該等財務報表已按照香港會計師公會頒布的《香港財務報告準則》真實而中肯地反映外匯基金及集團於2020年12月31日的財務狀況及截至該日止年度的財務表現和現金流量，並已按照行政長官在《外匯基金條例》（第66章）第7條下所發出的指示妥為擬備。

# 意見的基礎
